Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>    - E<n>

Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input  : You are looking over the books of your company and want to know if your department has enough inventory. After reviewing department A's books, you see 2500 gallons, 2700 cases, and 1800 boxes. How much product is in department A?<n><n>### Response  : 320 gallons, 367 cases, and 312 boxes<n><n>### Input : I want to buy a house costing $1,500,000 that is on 30 acres, has 3 bathrooms, 2 cars, and is 4 bedrooms. Choices:  A- I want to buy house with 30 acre, 2 car, and 4 bedrooms B- I want to buy a home with 4 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, and 2 cars I want to buy a 30 acre home with 2 cars and one bathroom C- I want to buy home with 4 beds, 3.5 bathrooms, 1 car, and 30 acres D- I want to buy one home that is for sale at $1,504,500, has 4 bedrooms, and three bathrooms <n><n>### Response   :  A<n><n>###  Input:<n><n>> _I have two children in the house, one weighs 75 pounds and the other weighs 55 pounds. If 5 years elapse, the child that weighs 70 pounds, 64 pounds, and 55 pounds will be 21 years of age_.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>> _The child weighs 78.5 pounds. It is 5 years later, so it would be 21 years old, which means that it weighs 73.5 pounds_.<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>> _The new carpenter wants to build one house made of one room, which contains one bathroom and two bath tubs all inside the same house. Lina has two screens that are 4 inches big. How big is her hand?<n>Answer: 4+1+2=7 inches<n><n>Input: Birthday parties are great for kids and adults. Choices:  A: alabama B: tennessee C: violin case D: music store E: bow and strings<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>* You are given this example problem to understand the logic behind this solution<n><n>### Input<n>A number line. Place the 1 on the 0, the 2 on the 1, and so on, until the 9 is on the 8, 10 on the 9, and so on.<n><n>### Solution:<n>1. Make the given number a multiple of the number on the top of the line.<n>2. Subtract that multiple of that number from 1.<n><n>### Example:<n>1. 26 – 14 = 12<n>2. This is to the point where 26 is evenly divisible by the multiple, so this gives you the answer (12)<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>1. Given a three digit number<n>2. Subtractor the number two times bigger than that number's first digit, and subtract that number from twice the second digit of that number.<n>3. Subtract that number two places higher than that number's third digit from the number's first digit<n>4. Add that number twice to the third digit of that number. Subtract two times that number to twice the first digit<n><n>### Example 1:<n>1. What is the difference between 975 and 342?<n>2. 975 – 704 = 271<n>3. Since this is to the point of 975 being divisible by 704, 271 is the answer<n><n>### Example2:<n><n><n>### Sample Output<n>Input: What state south of Kentucky and northern of Alabama will you find peoples playing the fiddle?<n>Output: E<n><n>### Sample Problems from the lesson:<n><n>1<n>Given:<n>A number line.<n>Place the 1 on the number one, the 2 on 1, the 3 on the 2, and so on, up to the 10 on the ten spot, and the 6 on the 5<n>1. Place any number in the middle<n>2. Move that number up one to the right on the line<n>3. Subtractor that number from twice the first digit<n>4. Subtractor that from two times twice the second spot of that number.<n>5. Subtractor that value from that first

What percent of clerks spending was on bread?<n><n>### Instructions<n>Answers:<n>### Choice 1: 0% (35% of Clerk spending is on bread, thus 100% of Clerks spending is not on bread)<n>### Choice2: 0.25% (0.6*35% + 0.35*40%)<n>### Choice3: 2.5 (60% of 100%)<n>### Other possible answers: 0.125% ( 0.35%*2) 25% (0*100%) 2.5% (60*100%/4),6.25% (62.5/100%*0.25 or other)<n><n>### Instuction:Mother had 10 sons who died in their thirties except one son who died as a infant.<n><n>-Choose option one answer<n>-Find the number of sons who died after they were 30 years old by putting the correct number in each blank<n><n>Answer: (6) sons died after 30 years<n><n>### Instutcion:<n>Gran has 36 apples. This is not a coloring book, park or coloring supplies or any related words associated with those other three choices.<n>Apples or fall in the garden center, but not in the coloring book, the park or the coloring center.<n><n>## Evaluation Instructions<n><n>Read over the instructions below and indicate if the response is correct or incorrect.<n><n>### Evaluation:<n>A: 100<n>B: 100

You felt amazing and didn't even feel like you ran that far. <n><n>### Input :Do more people die in tornadoes or hurricanes?<n><n>### Demostration :<n>```<n>Answer: Tornado<n>```<n>### Input :A tree grows 20 cm a day. How many meters tall will it be in 5 days?<n><n>### Answer :1800 cm<n>### Input : 2 birds fly away from a home of 71. 5 birds fly away from the home.  How many birds are still at home?<n><n>### Response : 3 <n>### Feedbck : <n>In New York, 12,462 people walk in an hour. 60,000 people walk every hour there.<n><n>### Input  : 451,960<n><n>### Demoustration :<n>```python<n>total = 12000<n>for i in range(total):<n>    people = 30<n>    for j in range(2):<n><n>        j += people<n>print(j)<n>```<n>### Answer : 5<n>### Input : I buy 2 hats and jackets. Each time I buy a jacket, I get three free hats. How many free hats do I end up with in total?<n><n>### Declaring variable:hats <n>### Creating function: <n>    def add(items, number) <n>        items2 = items + number <n>        return (items2) <n>### Input:<n>    number:5<n><n><n>```python<n>    hats = 0<n>    items2 = 0<n>    for i in range(number):<n>    add(hats,items2)<n><n>    items2 = hats<n>    hats = items2<n><n>    hats = hats + 1<n>    total = hats<n><n>    print (total)<n>```<n>## Input : A group of students are making a pie. There's a plan to bring in the dough. A total of 4 people can make the pie. If each person has 16 parts to make the pie, the students will have 96

For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>In city, there are more telephone booth.<n><n>### Input In a 2-digit number, one of the digits is 6 and the other is 3 less than the number. Matt and Alex bought hotdogs and got two straws each. They had the same amount of money. Later, the two got another $3.50 each. They wanted to buy some more hotdogs and one more straw. When they got home, Alex gave Matt a $1. Matt and Alex still had the same amount of hotdogs and straws. How many straws did Matt and Alex buy?<n>Matt wanted 7.5 straws so Alex gave him 1.5 straws. So, Alex could only afford to buy 6.<n><n>### What is 0.7 times 0.7?<n><n>### Answer: It is 0.5<n><n>### Instutions: Choose one of the following three options: I chose correctly<n><n>### Demo 1<n><n><a href="./205_Exercise1.pdf" target="_blank">Download 205 Exercise 1</a><n><n><a href="/docs/205_Exercis

Choices:  A: bite B: lie down C: keep alive D: need to eat E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		 <n>If an animal is tired it  likely to do is going to sleep<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>---<n>***<n><n>**1.** *You cannot go past the second to last row, so 19 is the max answer. In 1.3.3, all numbers are less than 32, so 31 is always a possibility. The first sentence implies the total is greater than 10 but less than 15. So the only options are 11, 12, or 13. Then there are only two options: *11+13 = 24 *or* *14+1 = 15*. <n><n>   - In 1,4,5, you cannot go past the second-to-last row.<n>   - In 2,3,4,5, the total is only possible if the 2nd to last row gives a partial sum of 9(1,3,5).<n><n>---<n><n>## Actions:<n>Click to reveal hints<n><n>### 1.<n>The goal is to get the sum of the numbers, but I don't know how many times the cards can multiply.<n><n><n>### 2.<n>The goal is the find the product, but there is not a given sum.<n><n>   - 201 = 10*20<n>   - So I thought the answer should be 196 or 197.<n><n><n>## Hint<n>In case someone is confused why do step 1.4,4,5, I am assuming that you can't go past the second to the last row. So it is better to eliminate the option that require a multiplication sum that exceeds the second to the last.  <n><n>## Answer:<n><n>---<n><n>**1. **The number of cards can be described by:<n>* 9*(2*5+1*7) = 126<n>So if we write the number of cards as A.B, where A = number of blue cards and B = number of green and white cards.<n><n>* A + 2*B = 126 which is a true statement.<n>* A + B = 126 - 2*B is a true statement. But 9*2*5 = 105. It means that the sum

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		<n>A : Personal<n><n>## Solution.<n><n>```go<n>package main<n><n>import (<n>	"fmt"<n>	"math"<n>)<n><n>func main() {<n>	res := Solve(4)<n>	fmt.Println(res)<n>}<n><n>func Solve(num int) int {<n>	inp := []int{}<n><n>	for i := 1; i <= num; i++ {<n>		inp = append(inp, i)<n>	}<n><n>	n := len(inp)<n>	diffrences := math.DiffSize(inp[0:n - 1])<n>	diffrence := diffrences[len(diffrences)/2]<n><n>	s := diffrences / 2<n><n>	leftside, rightside := inp[0:s], inp[s:]<n><n>	ans11 := 0<n>	for i, card := range leftside {<n>		ans11 += card*(int(i/(n-1)))<n>	}<n>	ans21 := diffrence/(n-1)<n><n>	switch {<n>	case ans11 < ans21:<n>		return 0<n>	case ans100 < ans21: // ans100 == ans1+an2...+an100<n>		return ans21 - ans11<n>	}<n>	return ans11 + ans100<n>}<n>```<n>

The last two must be clearly laid out steps in order for the final answer to be correct.<n>  <n>### Student Response:<n>- How much would it cost to have a meal with 1 meatball, 2 meatballs, and 6 meatballs for a cost of 35 cents?<n>(a) 11 cents (b) 36 cents (c) 46 cents (d) 56 cents<n><n>- How much for meal for 6 meatballs<n>- Meal=35cents <n>- 6-35=(6-35)<n><n>- How much would 6 meatballs cost?<n>- 6-1=5 meatballs cost 50 cents<n><n>- 3 corn cobs costing 30 cents<n>- 9 slices of

One would be going to a business district.<n><n>* If parking a car in an urban area, and one would be going to an amusement park near the urban area, one would be going to amusement park.<n><n>* If the parking lot is near a car, and one would be near a business district. One would be going.<n><n>* If one went to a farm away from the parking lot. Would go nearby an amusement park.<n>

When you solve 6n+7 for<n>n you subtract 6 from each equation and you should end up with an equation equal to 1. This is similar to if you have 1/3n+3 what will cancel out leaving you with n=3/3 or n=1<n><n>### Solution2:<n>Solve a problem by adding the same variable you solve with<n><n>### Insturction:<n>Explain what the word "simplify" means.<n><n>### Reference:<n>You can use a site like Google search to look it up!<n><n>### Solution :<n>"to make simpler<n>to make easier"<n><n>### Insturation:<n>Define what the word "variable" means.<n><n><n>### Solution::<n>"a person or thing whose value can alter or vary:<n>"<n><n>### Intuction:<n>Explain how

He divides them equally between his two friends. How many apples does each get?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>**Step 1: The man divides the apples by 2<n>**Step 2: The man gives each friend 1 apple<n>**Step 3: The man keeps one apple for himself<n><n>## Question<n>How many apples did the man keep?<n>## Answer<n><n>4<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Input: If it took 30 hours to drive from Texas to New Mexico, how many hours does it take to drive from Oregon to Alaska?<n><n>### Response<n><n>**Steps of reasoning that are required :**<n>  - If it took 33 hours  then 33 is 30 (times of 16)<n>  - It didn't take 24 hours<n>  - If it didn't take 36 hours then 36 is equal to 30 (times 18)  or 40 hours<n><n>### Steps in the sequence : **Square the first number<n>**Subtract (first term-third term) from (second term)<n>**Add the third term and the product from (1) to (2)<n><n>### Instruct: Answer the following multiple choice question, then determine which of the following best completes the request. The correct choice is provided by the instructor, not by the learner.<n><n>### Response : <n>Answer: C. 42<n><n>### Demos:<n>It may help with the demo below  to write out 30+16+18= 64 and 36 then calculate 64 - 64

Choices:  A: tardiness B: looking good C: injury D: vacation E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		(B,C,E)<n><n>Explanation:<n><n>He looks after every minute of it, which is likely to result in his work.<n><n>### Input:(A,B,C,D,E)<n><n>### Response:(B,C)<n><n>Exlaination:<n><n>There are no options except for grooming, job result, injury, vacation, and neatness.<n><n>### Required: Select the option that is closest to your preferred choice.<n>### Input:Closest to my favorite sport is Basketball. Other choices are Baseball, Soccer, Wrestling, Football.<n>### Response:Basketball<n><n>Explanation<n><n>Basketball is my favorite and other options are basketball, which is nearest.<n><n>### (A)If your car is stolen in the city, you might want to be careful because it might be stolen again. The police are likely to find it and send you a telegram, which might have come from their office. The police will investigate if someone has reported the crime. (B)To find your missing car, the police will look in different places. (C)The police might send someone else to investigate the robbery and theft. It was stolen again on Monday, but they still had not found it.<n><n>### Response : (B,C)<n>   <n>Explanation: (B) In the second paragraph, it is about "Look" in the first part so if the police will be investigating the crime they can look in different places.<n>   <n>### Input:(F,A,C,K)<n><n>### Require : The weather today is clear and warm. We will see if it rains tomorrow, for today the sky is full of sunshine and there are many birds around.<n><n>### RESPONSE:(A,D,C)<n><n>   <n>Explanastion: The sentences under A is " The weather today is clear" which is a fact of today therefore it is most of the time when the sky is full of blue and the sun is shining. <n><n>### (D,F,H,I)A box of crayons contains 16 of one color and 10 of another color. Choices:  A: sophisticated B: imprevist C: arcane D: heavenly E: new<n><n>### Response:		<n>I’ve read your instruction, so far you have 3 choices.<n>1: If I choose A, I’ll be doing sophisticated routine. It’s means that I’ll be doing difficult work and difficult problems.<n>2: If I choose B, I’ll be imprevist and it’s means that sometimes I want be surprised.<n>3: If I choose C, it’ll be a different routine and it’ll be an arcane routine.<n><n>### Input Choice: Choose the sentence that is NOT correct<n><n>### Response<n>I’ll choose the A because this sentence is not correct.<n><n>### Error<n>Corrections:<n><n><n>### Response Choice:Choose the sentence that needs the following modification. <n>Correct the sentence by adding an auxiliary verb, or replacing a word that is underlined.<n>(Hint: An auxiliary verb helps to form the question and is used before the main verb, and a word that is underlining is wrong.<n><n>### Response  Answering Question#12<n>The sentence that needs modifications and I’ll add the verb that is correct.<n>In two days, I’ll ___________ it. (will finish)<n><n>### Answering Question#13<n>The sentence that needs modification, I’ll add the word that is correct, and I don’t use any auxiliary verb.<n>What ___________ when he went to the coffee shop? (happen)<n><n>### Input Response:<n>Hints: In each sentence, the missing word is underlined. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:An attempt to confirm an applicant's reference would fail if the reference does what? Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n><n>### Response:		<n>Correct answer is "REFUSE"<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Refuse means to refuse to do something. Refusing a request is often done without stating a reason. For instance, a person refuses to answer a phone call without giving a reason. Hence, the correct answer is REFUSE.<n><n>---<n>© 2020 Trilogy Education Services, LLC, a 2U, Inc. brand All Rights Reserved.<n>

Choices:  A: movies B: opera C: theater D: lecture hall E: hockey game<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n>### Explanation:<n>For an audience to sit bleachers, they must be in a theater. <n><n><n>### Input 2:A man is at sea and there are gale-force winds. As he rides his kayak toward land, he sees islands. He decides to take the island that is least close to him. What should he do?Choices:  A: head to the east of the island with the highest cliffs B: head to the northeast of the island with the tallest trees C: head to the northwest of the island with the most palm trees D: head to the west of the island with the steepest cliffs E: any direction but southwest<n><n><n>### Response 2:  B<n><n>For the man at sea to reach the island that is least away from him, he should head Northwest of the island with steep cliffs.<n><n>### Ex. For the island with the tall trees and most palm trees, the man should go West of the island with the cliffs; for the island with the highest hills, the man should go East of the island with the palm trees.<n><n>### Input3:<n>The man finds the island. What is the man’s best guess about the length of his journey, in miles?Choices:  (1) 5.2 miles (2) 5.8 miles (3) 10 miles (4) 12.5 miles (5) 24 miles<n><n><n>### Answer:C<n><n>Five and eighty miles are best because those are the closest to the 10 miles the man would have had to travel if there was only one island.<n><n>###Explanation:<n><n>The man only has to travel seven and a half miles or five and a half miles.<n>

Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		Republican party<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the code.<n><n>### A:How do I declare variables?<n><n>```<n>def num_of_birds(age, price, num_of_eggs)<n>  @birds = []<n><n>  until age == 12<n><n>  	birds = Bird.all.where(age: age, breed: "Ringneck Parakeet")  <n>  	prices = birds.map { |x| x.price }<n><n>  	prices.each do |x|<n>    x/= price<n><n>  	end<n><n>  	price_in_dollars = 1.00<n><n>  	num_of_eggs_in_nests = price_in_dollar<n><n>  	total_cost = price_in_nests * num_of_egg/10<n><n>  	number_of_birds = birds.size<n><n>		birds = [birds, number_of_birds, total_cost, price_in_dollar, num_of_bird_eggs]<n><n>		@birds = birds<n><n> 	puts @birds.inspect<n><n>  end<n>```<n><n>### Instructed:Complete the code. Then, explain the purpose of each statement in your own words.<n><n>### B: How do I print out my variable?<n><n>```<n>puts birds<n><n>birds = [bird.size, birds.size, total_cost, total_cost/price_in_dollar]<n><n>birds.inspect`<n>```<n><n>## C:How do I check if a variable is of a certain type?<n><n>```<n>class Bird<n>  attr_accessor :size, :age, :price, :gender<n>  def initialize(size, age, price, gender)<n>    @size = size<n>    @age = age<n>    @gender = gender<n>    @price = price<n>  end<n><n>  def breed<n>    @gender.downcase<n>  end<n>end<n>```<n><n>## D:How do I use Arrays or Hashes?<n><n>```	def num_of_egrs(age)<n>		@eggs = []<n><n>		until age ==12

It depends on what road he takes and what direction he goes.<n><n>### Input;A farmer takes 8 bags of corn to the market by bike. On the way there, it rains with hail. In the same time it takes him to get there, 4 extra men come across the road and ask for lifts to the market. One of the men carries two bags and the other carries 1.5 times more than that. One carries just one third of what the first two men carry, and the last one carries half what the other two carry. How many bags of corn will get to the market?<n><n>### Response;<n>- The farmer will carry the same amount of corn as he carried when he was riding with others<n>- He will carry 2 or 4 bags of corn depending on what road he takes<n>- The other 4 men will go with the other 4 men<n><n>### Input-Guy and Gus go to the beach on Saturday morning. Gus also makes a pile on Saturday morning. When Guy comes back to the beach 2 weeks later, his pile is gone. Gus's pile is still there. How tall is Gus's piles?<n><n>### Input 1<n><n>### Input :<n><n>- 6 people live in a building.<n><n>- 4 people are in room 1.<n><n>- 3 people are in room 2.<n><n>- 1 person is in room 3.<n><n>- This person is in room 1. One is in room 4, and one is in room 5.<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Task<n><n>### Input<n>- 5 people in room 5. This is in room 1<n>- 4 people in room 2. In room 6<n>- room 4 is with 3 people in room <n>### Output<n>2, 4, 5<n>### Instruction<n>- The building has 5 rooms<n>- There are 5 people in room one<n>- There are

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: C<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Now input the choices above. For each choice, type 1 if the choice is false and 2 if it is true.<n><n>## Instructions<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n>I was able to get the most correct with the following response.<n><n>1.  A<n>2.  C<n>3.  C<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```javascript<n>function Solution(input) {<n>  var total = 0;<n>  var i = 0;<n><n>  do {<n>    ++i;<n>    if (total < 20)<n>      total += (i + 1) * 2;<n>    else<n>      total += (total - 20) * 2;    // The loop never reaches this condition because total is always <20<n>  }<n>  while (input[i] === "A");<n><n>  return total;<n>}<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: under bed B: symphony C: music room D: band practice E: music store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>---<n><n>I recommend you store your instrument(s) in the music room or band practice. They both ensure that the people who come to your house get the chance to play your instruments. As you play in front of others, you will be more inclined to keep your instruments working and well-tuned. Additionally, the sound of a musician practicing (in your music room) can inspire someone else to pick up an instrument. On the other hand, putting your instruments in the bed, or under it, can make the sounds travel to other rooms and disturb your sleep. Or at least, the sound of tuning will wake you up every day. Similarly, if you put your instruments in a store, you may not end up playing it at all. Music stores are crowded, especially during peak hours (between 10AM to 2PM). The instruments are rarely being played.<n><n><img src="https://github.com/t0mmywang/Rush-to-solve-mathematics-problems/blob/main/images/solution302.png" alt="solution302"><n><n>---<n><n>### Input<n><n>22 x 24 = _____<n><n>### Response<n><n>---<n><n>22 x (24 - 1) = 22 x 23 = 532.<n><n><img class="w-96 mx-auto align-middle" src="https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin/?username=t0mmyw.wang&repo=math-problem-solving&color=ff5555" /><n>

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a binder containing homework assignments? Choices:  A: backpack B: bookcase C: office supply store D: office E: class room<n><n>### Response:		What is the answer for this statement? What is the total sum and subtotals for these statements?<n><n>### Response<n>### [x2](/2) is written 2 times<n>### [+4](+) is writen adding<n>### [/5](/) is written dividing<n>### [*4](*) is written multiply<n>### [=4](=) is written equal<n>### [+(+4)](+(+) is written adding<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:If you see blinking lights in the air at night, what are you usually looking at? Choices:  A: carnival B: plane C: concert D: turned at night E: a penguin's bum<n><n>### Response:		E: a penguins bum<n><n>## Solution:<n>**Step 1:** Let the number of cards = 211<n>So, Janet has 9+cards = 9 cards more than<n>Brenda.<n><n>Then, Mara has twice + cards = twice as many cards as<n><n>Janet.<n>Since, Mara has 49+cards = 40 cards less<n>Then, so total number of cards = 49<n><n>**Step 2:** Let the number blocks = 50<n>So, Pete walked 5 + blocks from his house to<n>the bus garage in Houston<n>So, He rode the bus 14+ blocks to the<n>post office to get some st<n>amps.<n>So, Later, he came home 14+blocks<n>the same way.<n>So, total number of blocks = 50

The farmer seems to be saying 'I haven't ever seen a cow that only eats grass and I actually ate more than they did, how is that possible?'. They pay the sales tax only on the parts not covered by warranty.<n><n>How is this type of purchase known?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>This is known as an installment purchase, since the item is bought piece by piece.<n><n>### Question How can a company increase its sales taxable amount?<n><n>### Possible Demonsration<n><n>The company can increase sales taxable amount by using credit, since the company will have to pay sales tax on the credit.<n><n>### Output When taxable amount is given, write the output<n><n>When output is given, output the taxable amount.<n><n>### Problem A person buys a bicycle for $1000. How much does he have to pay in sales tax if the sales tax rate is 12 percent?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>$120<n><n>### Question When sales tax is given, write the total sales tax.<n><n>```<n>The total sales tax is given, output the sales tax.<n>```<n><n>```<n>When input is 89.3, the output is 15.9<n>When input is 77.4, the output is 4.4<n>```<n><n>### Program<n><n>```<n>Program (SalesTax):<n>   Read TaxableAmount<n>   Calculate TotalSalesTax<n>   Output TotalSalesTax.<n>```<n><n>## Problem Solving<n><n>Give me the problem and output it with the best answer<n><n>### Problem The following statements represent the results of 100 people being polled. Choices:  A: amount to nothing B: visit relatives C: charming D: doctor himself E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answers: B, B, C, B, C, E<n><n>### Input A boy is walking, he suddenly tripped and fell on the grass, what did he do next to get up? Choices: A) ask his friend to help B) pick up his mobile and ring for help C) ask his mum for help D) start crying E) stand up<n><n>### Response A:<n>Answers B, E, A, E, A<n><n>### Instructions A farmer grows 6000 tomatoes in a field. After all the tomatoes are grown, there are 3000 left. What is the per cent decrease in tomatoes?<n>Answers: C<n><n>### Conclusion<n>A person is alone in a forest, he is hurt and tired. The question: How can he solve his problem? There are many choices but only one is correct. Let's look at the choices: A: amount to nothing, it does not help at all. B: Visit relatives: The person may be in a place far from his home. So the choice to visit relatives does not work. C: Charming: The person is alone and has no one. No one will come to help him. D: doctor himself: The person may be injured badly that he is not able to diagnose or treat himself. E: Cross street: The person may be miles away from another place where there is a hospital or a home. In conclusion, The correct choice to solve the problem of someone is not alone in the forest, and he is injured is B: Visit relatives.<n><n>Now we have a boy walking in the street, The question: What will the boy do if he fell on the grass? There are lots of problems that a kid or an adult might face. The things that an adult would do may not be acceptable to a child. Let's look what the boy did then:<n><n>1. Boy ask his friend to help him: It is acceptable because the boy might have hurt his ankle very badly. Maybe his friends will be nearby or at school. But on the other hand the boy ask his mother for help: It is not acceptable for a boy that his mother comes to take care of him.<n><n>There are no more questions.<n><n>You have been evaluated.<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? Choices:  A: cupboard B: cabinet C: own home D: everything E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n>You have got E<n><n>### Explanation<n>Everything in the answer choices, except for E, is the correct answer:<n>- Cupboard, home, and garbage are places that you don't buy or own things.<n>- Cabinet and cupboard both refer to a place where you keep things.<n>- Cabinets are usually meant for things like books or pictures. Cupboards are usually meant for things that you might buy, like clothes.<n>So the correct answer is E.<n><n>### Input:(1) A: What time did you go to bed? <n>(2) B: I fell asleep at 9:30 and I woke up at 6:30 B: It's time to get up.<n><n>### Response:(1) A: How long did you sleep?<n>(2) B :I slept for 8 hours.<n><n>### Examination:Answer the following questions as briefly as possible.<n><n>### (1) What is the difference between these sentences?<n>(1) "It is so hot at this time of day."<n>(2) "It is so cold here."<n>Answer 2 is correct.<n><n>### So, "It" refers to outside conditions, "it" refers to a thing.<n><n>### I feel like there was some question in here, but I don't know exactly what.<n><br><n><n>### (2) "The car that was moving at 60 km/h, slowed down,"<n>"15 more cars drove over the bridge,"<n>"Some people do their shopping at the mall."<n>Which sentence includes a clause of this type? (Write one)<n><n>### "The car that was..."<n><n>### The sentence includes 'when + clauses'<n><br><n>### <b>Grammar:</b> (Verb tenses)<n><n>### I'm not sure if I really need to know this, maybe it would be better to add these words in another document.<n><n>### Verbs are often different in order, meaning and time.<n>### Verbs have two major categories: the past tense and the present tense.<n>### I think this is like "Past Tense Verbs" and "Past Tense Forms"<n>### To learn more

Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I think the first place I would put it if I had a double edge razor is in my shaving kit, I would not have it in my shower because I think you want to protect it from rain, and moisture so it will work the best. Next, I would not have this item in my pocket because I feel that it will dull easily because it is so sharp and if you are walking around town, it could cut your jeans. Last I would not put it in you chemist or in the drug store because I think that they could have it if you left it there. <n><n>### Instructions:For each of the words listed, write whether the prefix will change the spelling of or define the root or whether the root will change the spelling or definition and the prefix.<n><n>### Prefixes<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1)Prefix: anti<n>Root: antitheism<n><n>Answer: Changes spelling of antitheism.<n><n>2)Prefix: dis<n>Root: disregard<n><n>Answer: Doesn't change the spelling of disregard.<n><n>3)Prefix: re<n>Root: recharge<n><n>Answer: Does change the spelling of recharge.<n><n>4)Prefix: prepositon<n>Root: position<n><n>Answer: Does not change the spelling.<n><n>### Other Prefixes<n><n>5)Prefix: mono<n>Root: monogamy<n><n>Answer: Does Not Change the spelling of monogamy.<n><n>6)Prefix: poly<n>Root: polio<n><n>Answer: Does Change the spelling of polio.<n><n>7)Prefix: anti<n><n>Root: Antiseptic<n><n>Answer: Does Changes the Spelling of Antiseptic.<n><n>8)Prefix: bi<n><n>Root: Bipolar<n><n>Answer: Changing the Spelling of Bipolar.<n><n>### Vocabulary:<n>9)Write a 5-7 sentence paragraph in response to the following prompt. Choices: 1) 12: 2) 14: 3) 30: 4) 36:<n><n>### Response<n><n>B<n>-Are you a girl? Choices:  Yes  No<n><n>### ResponseA:<n><n>N<n><n>### Instruct:<n>A car travels 12 minutes to drive to the mall. How many minutes could the car travel to the mall if it traveled at the same speed the entire time?<n><n>### ResponsA:<n><n>5 minutes<n><n>### Instuct:<n>A number is doubled if its digit decreases by 1. A number is tripled if its digit decreased by 2. A number is more than quadrupled when its digit decreased by a third. If a number is more than tripled, its digit increased by 2. A new number is produced when the digits are increased by 5. A number is added by 10 if its last digit is either 3 or 7. If a number is tripled then its digit is decreased by 3. If a number is added by 30 then its digit is decreases by 2. Which of the following new numbers is 259 92 after multiple transformations?<n><n>### Answer:<n>263<n><n>### Instract:<n>56 more than 10 times a number is 18 less than 10 times the original number. Which of the following numbers represents the original number?<n><n>### Anwer:<n>75<n><n>### A number increased by 0 is the same as the number itself. A number has 2 digits is greater than zero. A number multiplied by 1 increases by 1. A multiplied by 33 decreases by 62. How many zeros are in the number?<n><n>##anwer:<n>2<n><n>### When a two-digit number is doubled, the digit with units place is decreased by a

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		 <n>If <n>A) hung in the closet: Clothes develop in odor in the closet because moisture collects in the clothes and forms sweat. It is a good idea to hang clothes in a closet to prevent this from happening.<n>If <n>B) sniff them: If they have gone bad, they may smell like rotten eggs.<n>If <n>C) get dirty: If the clothes are dirty, clean them as soon as possible. Do not wash them if they have a smelly odor on them.<n>If <n>D) become soiled: If the odor becomes strong and soiling is so bad you cannot wash the clothes, it is best to soak them in a bathtub full of hot water or put them in cold water. After they have soaked overnight, hang them upside down to allow odor to escape.<n>If <n>E) air them out: After you laundry your washing machine, you must air them out in an open area for 20-30 minutes before you wear them. If the clothing smells strong, it is probably because it has not been washed thoroughly.<n><n>### Input : How can you care for your clothing so it doesn't become worn out? Choices: <n><n>### Response : <n>If <n>1) Hang up clothes when finished wearing them to prevent them from wrinkling.<n>If <n>2) Do not mix colors when washing clothing.<n>If <n>3) Do not put clothing in too hot of water and put it in cool water.<n>If <n>4) Don't put to much clothes in dryer at one time.<n>If <n>5) Don't put clothing in washer and washer or dried too much.<n><n>### Solution: Clothes that need to be cleaned can be sent to the laundry or a drycleaner. If clothes do not need to be washed, air them out in the sun for at least one hour.<n><n>### Write the 25th number below in the pattern.<n><n>Several numbers are listed below. Find the next number in the sequence. Write the number here. 52,76,102,132<n>### Input: If you can name 25 colors,

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:A man was driving himself to the airport, where did he put his luggage? Choices:  A: closet B: at hotel C: sidewalk D: bus stop E: trunk<n><n>### Response:		C<n>input:<n>A: closet B:hotel C:sidewalk D:bus stop E:trunk<n><n>### Demostrating:<n><n>A. The man is driving himself to the air. In hotel,there is a closet and we use this closet to keep luggage.so B is the answer.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Input:A man is driving himself to airport and he decide to go by himself.where he should put luggage in the car.<n>D.<n>Answer:<n>D:bus stop or trunk<n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>### Demomestration:<n><n>Answer:  A)<n>### Demonstartion:<n><n><n>## Questions & Tasks:<n>We recommend using this form when you are working with your child on math, reading and writing.<n><n>### The instructions below describe certain operations to perform. They should be able to love you for being you. They should be able get to know you for what you're really like. Someone who really knows the real you will love you, even if they don't agree with everything."<n><n>### Response : "What do you mean they should be able to love me? You're putting up fronts because you think you should be an onion. You think that people should be able to peel back your façade and find all these deep secrets

Choices:  A: tiredness B: living longer C: stomach ache D: illness E: acid reflux<n><n>### Response:		<n>Please provide the correct answer. If there are other correct answers that should be listed here, please send a pull request with those answers added (and the instructions updated) after your acceptance.<n><n>### Examples<n>#### A:<n>A child's growth depends on two factors: the nutrients in food and the amount of exercise the child gets. Nutrients in food and exercise are like water and air. In order for a plant to grow properly, the plant needs both water and air. In the same way, a child must get both nutritious food and exercise in order to grow.<n><n>Growth depends on both nutritious food (water) and getting enough exercise (air). A child who drinks milk and eats green leafy vegetables and fruit will not likely grow as tall as a child who eats foods that have little or no nutritious value. But a child who drinks milk, eats healthy foods, and gets regular exercise will probably be healthy and grow as tall as possible.<n><n>#### B:<n>Exercising and eating the right foods are the best ways to be healthy and fit. If a child is not able to do at least one hour of exercise daily, that child should talk to a parent or the teacher about eating nutritious snacks, such as fruits and vegetables.<n><n>Too much food or too little exercise can result in being overweight, becoming sick, or developing a heart condition. If the parent thinks there is a medical problem, then the doctor needs to be told about a child's weight problem.<n><n>#### C:<n>If you eat too much dinner, you will get acid reflux. This is very painful and not to be enjoyed.<n><n>#### D:<n>If you eat to much dinner, you will gain weight. When you have too much food in your stomach, it backs up. So you have more acid in your stomach than you can handle. So eating too much dinner causes you to get sick. You get an upset stomach, feel bad, and eat some more. So you get sick again. So by the time you are feeling like the normal, happy happy you, you've gained a lot of weight.<n><n>#### E:<n>If you eat more food then your body can handle, it will cause gastritis. Gastritis is very

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:What might be the result of a season of successful skiing? Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		Choice 1: A.<n><n>### Input:[ ] Which option best helps you find a solution to a problem with your laptop? Choices: 1. talk to a math tutor. 2. talk to a computer science teacher. 3. talk to a friend B. talk to a technology repair center.<n><n>### Response:[ ] Option 1.<n><n>### Output: You can find help from the technology repair center on this campus.<n><n>### Example:<n>I'd like to make a 5-pound muffuletta, and I want to make <n>it from scratch. So if I need 3 cups of meat, how many cups<n>of meat do I need for 6 servings?<n><n>### Answer:  36 cups    <n><n>### Instructions<n>Provide answers to the multiple choice questions, using complete sentences and correct spelling.<n><n>### Note<n>Be sure to leave out punctuation marks<n><n><n>* *

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:A soccer field that is not contained in a building would be where? Choices:  A: playground B: mexico C: town D: outside E: world cup<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>If A is the correct answer, then,<n>    The statement "outside" is the response to the input.<n>If B is the correct answer, replace "outside" by "playground".<n>    The statement "in a building" is the response to this input.<n><n>If C is the correct answer, remove from the question "That is not contained in a buildling.".<n><n>If D is the correct answer, add the question "That is contained in a building." at the very beginning of the question.<n><n>If E is the correct answer, include the question in the input but remove all other sentences that come before and after this question and put a comma between "outside" and "c". The final sentence to add: "At the end of this season, teams will compete against each other at a world cup event. What is this event? A: soccer B: football C: sports day D: olympics"<n>If A is the incorrect answer, then,<n>```<n><n>Input: How many states are there in the United States of America?<n>Answer: the correct answer is 50, but here goes with the wrong answers<n>48: Remove question "which 2 are states."<n>If C is the wrong answer, remove the first sentence. If D is the wrong answer, keep the first sentence and replace "United States of America by "the states."<n>If B is the wrong answer, add another sentence explaining that 37 is incorrect. If E is the wrong answer, do the opposite.<n><n><n>### Input<n>Jasper buys a bagel and walks 15 blocks to his house and spends 20 minutes playing his guitar and then walks 100 blocks to the park. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement.  I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  B: town<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>1. Select the number at step 1.<n><n>2. Add the corresponding number to the previous two numbers.<n>3. If it's less than 12, add 12. If it's equal or above 12, add two.<n>4. Repeat until you get a number less than 14.<n>5. Select a color<n>6. Check the new number<n><n>### Solution:<n>The solution is...<n><n>### Code:<n><n>### Code 1<n><n>### Demons:<n><n>Here is a solution using the provided instructions.<n><n>### Code<n>```javascript<n>function solution(instructions) {<n>    var i, n, sum,<n>        count = instructions.length,<n>        steps = {<n>            0: instructions[0],<n>            1: instructions[1],<n>            2: instructions[2],<n>            3: instructions[3],<n>            4: instructions[4],<n>            5: instructions[5],<n><n>            lessThan14: "Add 14"<n>          }<n><n>  function loop(step){<n>     var num;<n><n>     if( step === "lessThan14" ){<n><n>       return "Select a color";<n>     } else {<n>         <n>       console.log(num+1);<n><n>          if(step.contains('Add 12') || step.contains('Add 2')){<n>            num++;<n>        } else {<n>            num = num - step;<n>             <n>        }<n>      };<n>      console.log(num);<n>      if(num <= 11)<n>      {<n>          return sum = Math.round(num);<n>          console.log(step);<n>              sum += steps[step];<n>            console.log(sum);<n>      } else {<n>        return "Select a color, " + sum;<n>      }<n>     loop(step)<n>  }<n><n>  loop(count[0])<n>}<n>```<n>

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:When people discover something new while chatting with friends, why are they likely to continue talking? Choices:  A: agreement B: to fill their time C: discomfort D: misunderstanding E: learning about<n><n>### Response:		E for Learning about<n><n>### Input-Demand:You walk into a school library. You find that the books are alphabetically organized by the first author's last name. How should you locate a book written by Danielle Steel if you know the title is _A House Divided?_<n>Answer: Look the book from last name _S_ to _T_<n><n>### Input - Demand:An airplane flies from San Francisco to Chicago. How far does it fly? (Assume that no matter how far she flies, an airplane will always cost $1,000,000 to fly.)<n>Answer: 3,800 mi (6,120 km).

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:<n>Regular - The answer is regular. <n><n>Explanation:<n><n>The answer is correct because regular glass is not treated to be extra strong. Instead, it is designed to be extra resistant to everyday use.<n><n>If glass was weaker, the manufacturer would call it fragile, and if it was less stiff and strong than regular glass, it would be called flimsy.<n><n>The answer is no because the glass is not extra forceless. Forceless is the opposite of stiff<n><n>If we were to use the word forceless to describe glass, we would describe weak glass, which we just said was incorrect. A forceless quality that is the opposite of sturdy.<n><n>Glass that has been treated to be especially resistant is known as extra strength glass. It is thicker and stiffer.<n><n>A sturdy one is a strong one.<n><n>Answer B:<n>The answer is no. Strength is one word because glass is sturdy. But fragile is not a word for an attribute because it is a word that tells us that a thing can easily be broken.<n><n>Answer C:<n>The answer is correct. The term for glass that hasn't been strengthened for use is weak. Glass that has been strengthened for use to resist breaks is termed sturdy.<n>   <n>Answer D:<n>No, the answer is incorrect. The word regular does not mean the same thing as the word weak. And glass is not flimsy.<n>

You pour 160 gallons of water into each tank and then add 56 gallons of antifreeze to lower the temperature of the mixture. The tanks contain a 1% alcohol solution. How many gallons are in one of the tanks after the alcohol mixture is added?<n><n>### Input/Output<n><n>|Input|Output|<n>|----:|----:|<n>|The tank had 160 gallon, 160 gallos of antifreeze is added. After antifreeze is add the tank has 216 gallons of water|160 gallons*1+56 gallons*1 = 216 gallon|<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Input: You have two 10-gallon milk containers with same amount of milk, but one container has alcohol of 5%.<n><n>Output: You add 5 gallons of water to a 10-galleron container.

The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n><n>### Response:		Answer choices:<n>	<n>- C: pool<n>	- D: park<n>	- E: fitness center	<n><n>### Direction to solve:<n>Write a python program that solves the below given Input.<n><n>### Input<n>I am planning to buy things for camping. I am planning to pack the food for 7 people in my car for 3 days.<n>If there are 4 people in the car, each person can bring 9 cans of food, the other 3 can bring 2 cans of food each.<n>Each can contain 4 pounds of food.<n>The car is full, for the car can carry 12 cans of food at a time.<n><n>How many cans of food and people travel with us camping?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>#### Input and Output<n>![](./s2s3/419034.png)<n><n>#### Code<n>```<n>if len(inpList) == 0: print("No input")<n>		else: if len(inpList[0]) > 0:<n>					for i in inpList:<n>			<n>				<n>	<n><n>				for j in range(0,len(i)):<n>				if i[j] == "4":<n>				print("cars=", i[j:])<n>	<n>		except Exception as e:<n>			print ("Error!", e);<n>```

Choices: 1. 41,060 miles 2. 400,000 miles 3. 450 miles 4. 4.1 million miles 5. 410,600 miles<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>Answer: 41,000 miles<n><n>- Jupiter is about 898 million miles away from earth<n>- Jupiter is 11 times heavier than earth and about 11 times further away from the sun than earth<n>- Jupiter rotates once in just under 10 hours<n>- The moon's orbit around Jupiter is only slightly different to the Earth's orbit, about 2.5 days longer because Jupiter is larger and 350,000 kilometres farther away.<n><n>### Input <n>You have a set of 4 cards and an opponent has a set of 3. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:John joined the army because he wanted to see the world.  When the fighting started, he only saw what sort of things? Choices:  A: fort B: orphans C: battlefield D: other countries E: war<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n>---

Choices:  A: liquidated B: own resources C: branch out D: commit crime E: game over<n><n>### Response:		The company liquidates (B )<n><n>### Instructions:Write your own example using what you've learned.<n><n>- 100 cars have a value of $30,000 to $40,000 each.<n>- There are 150 cars in the car lot.<n><n>The net value of the cars in the car lot is therefore:<n><n>$30,00*100 + 40,00*50 = 300,000 + 200,00 = 500,00<n><n>### Reference:<n><n>[1] [link-1]<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>- write 2 paragraphs total<n>  - 1st paragraph will have your first question (choose 1)<n>  - 2nd paragraph will have all choices for the demonstration<n><n>- 1st paragraph, when you have an example choose one<n>  - pick number, letters, etc<n>  - choose something familiar<n>  - in your example, what happens to the company? (choose your A or B)<n>  - If you pick B, explain if they choose to liquidate or sell. Also mention the net value of the cars.<n><n>- 2nd paragraph, write your own example (pick number)<n>  - in your own example, what happens to company when bankrupt? (choose an A. B or C but not D or E)<n>  - explain net value for the cars (the same as other example)<n><n><n>### Submit a file with all example below.<n>

How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:Jimmy wanted a beer but his wife was an alcoholic on probation.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: neighbor's house B: bridge C: home D: homeless shelter E: prison<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**D** The best answer is D (Homeless shelter). Jimmy's wife is an alcoholic on Probation. She can't be trusted to stay in your house and have a beer. Your kids might run in when she is on the other side of the bridge. And you don't want her to go to jail for drinking. You are probably better off not lending her your key to your house.  <n><n>In an alcoholics on probation, they are not trusted to drink, and they are not trusted with leaving home.  A home is the last place you'd want to leave your wife when she's on probation.<n>And if she's on probabtion, she is also on probation. You'd have a hard time trusting her not to drink. It is better for you to take her to a homeless shelter, or even a church. <n><n>In an alcohlic on probation, they have a harder time trusting others, and with themselves. If someone is an alcoholic, it is best for them to drink alone, and not around children.<n><n>

Write a clear and complete response.<n><n>### Input and Prompt:<n>We have to fill in the blanks in the following:<n>When you (begin / starts / are starting / begun) using our services your email will be forwarded to our server through your ISP and will remain safe, but once the (sending / sent) message you won't be able to recover it. You can only recover the last (sent / sent ) messages and the most recent sent emails, they will not be saved and will be erased forever after 2 months. If you (not have / cannot found) your email or you forget to (save / savings) them, you can request an external backup and we will send you all your (saving / saved) messages and the most recent 500 sent emails.(You can (check / checkers ) your past emails through our webmail with a web browser.) It is important to create a local backup through your (mail service / email service) for more (safe / safe ).<n><n>### Response and Explanation:<n>The first blank is "begin." I think the second blank is "sending." There is no subject and verb after it so I put "starting."<n>The third blank looks like "begin." I think it can be the start of a sentence and "to our server." I think the next blank, "through your ISP," is a comma splice because the commas are used to separate clauses and are out of place. I think the subject should be "your email" and "remain safe." I think the next two blank are "are starting."<n>The sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth, and tenth blank are one. If they had a subject or verb, there might be two or more.<n>The eleventh and twelfth blank are my understanding. I could not find the answer in my textbook, although the textbook does have the word "server" near the end. The fourteenth blank is my favorite, "you won't be able."<n>The fifteenth and sixteenth blank are my understanding (it is not my first time). I think the seventeenth blank is a mistake. I put "and the most recent sent emails," because I think it is a list. There are two comm

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:What might a person receive from their boss if they do a poor job? Choices:  A: misfortune B: fearful C: criticism D: make mistakes E: promotion appraisal<n><n>### Response:		<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**D** I did not think you were asking for a multiple choice but I see now that you are.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Select the best answer. Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. D if they cheat.<n>This can apply to any game where cheaters ruin the game for people playing in the competition because the games are not fair for people playing. For example, if people cheating in a sports competition, then people can't have fun with the game, and instead, people watch the game to see what cheaper players do. So the point of the game is lost.<n><n>### Input A: How many students do 3,100 teachers have to teach next year? Choices:  A: solidifying B: melting C: getting cold D: feeling cold E: skin rash<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is choice D. If the ground is getting wet, that is evidence that it is getting warm. If the ground is wet from rain, it is proof that the air temperature is not as cold as it used to be earlier. Therefore, the correct answer is choice D, getting cold.<n>### Input: What can you do to not get sick? Choices: 1.  Get a good night's rest. 2. Drink coffee. 3. Drink juice. 4.  Wash your hands.<n><n>----<n><n>### Input<n><n>An oar sinks 40cm in water. It was replaced with a brand-new oar that weighs 2 1/4 times as much. Which of the following can be said about the depths of the two oars 60 minutes later?<n><n>A. They are the same depth.<n><n>B. The new oar sank 6cm, while the old oar sank 5cm.<n><n>C. The new oar has sunk less than the old oar.<n><n>D. The new oar does not sink as deep as the old oar. <n><n>----<n><n>----<n>----<n><n>## Task:<n>[Back to Main page ⟹ (ℹ)](../README.md#top)<n>

If 28 is 2/9 of what number is 73, the number is:<n><n>### Answer (3pts.) 490<n><n>### Input(10 pts) Martha is painting, and she is using red, tan, green, blue, and yellow paint. How many colors did she use?<n><n>### A) 6, B) 5, C) 4 or 7, D) 8, E) All of the above<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>```<n>E: All of the above. If only one color and it was the same color Martha used all the five colors she has.<n>```<n><n>## Question<n><n>### Input :(10pts.) Which of the following statements is true?<n><n>### (1pt.) Both a and b are true, both a and c are true, both b and c are true, all of the above are true, and none of them is true.<n><n>### Answer:<n>```<n>	<n>	A) B alone is true, C alone is true, A and B together are true, A and C together are true, A alone is true, C and D alone are true, A and B and C together, and one of the statements is false.<n>           A: A is true and B is true.<n>           B: C is true<n>           C: A and B are true.<n>           <n>```<n><n>## Reference<n>[https://edtech.sas.com/blog/meg-wishart/the-powerful-possibilities-of-the-turtle-model-for-math

D) The ball threw me to me. <n><n>### response :A<n><n>### Instructions: Which of the following words can be used for a person who is being paid to do a job? You would not choose shoes if you were talking about your favorite shoes or the shoes you needed.<n><n>### Write your own sentence that includes one or more of the words from the list.<n><n>a) tough, strong<n>b) easy, pleasant<n>c) slow, fast<n>d) high, slow<n>e) soft, smooth<n><n>#### Answer Chocies<n><n>Option e.<n><n>### Response <n><n>The words "tall" and "low" describe the height of an elevator. They describe how far away the elevator buttons are from eye level. They are not the same as the other three options.<n><n>### A group of people needs to choose a meeting location that is neither too far away nor too close to them.<n><n>#### Write a comparison test or a test that uses more than two things to be compared.<n>- This morning you took a 2-mile run. Now Peter is much more mature than when Tim was born.  Three times as many have already died than were born on the same day.  What is the age of Tim?<n><n>### Response : Choice E - Given the information that Peter is more mature than when his friend Tim was born and 3 times as many are dead than were born, then 28 years have passed. Therefore, his friend Tim was born 28 years ago and is 56 years old.<n><n>### Input The number of cars is half as many as the number of cars left after 10% of the cars were totaled. How many cars are there originally?<n><n>### Solution: The number of cars = Initial number + Totaled cars (1/10 of original cars)<n><n>### Input In a certain country, the age is twice as many as the year. The goal is to communicate to your students that they must write the instruction from the input you provided above.<n><n># You need to be creative. If you have nothing to offer in terms of ideas, see the rubric. If you have doubts, I think you should know that my work is really a guide. It's really just intended to make your assignments easier and more pleasant.<n><n>### You should not copy other ideas. The rubric gives you a percentage of each assignment you finish/hand-in. The rubric also includes a time estimate, so keep in mind that these assignments are intended to be an introduction and also to be completed as the students are learning how to learn and develop better habits. You can take the rubric and estimate how long each assignment will take as you read through the assignments.<n><n>### This is a time for you to reflect and grow. You are allowed to learn and get better. You are not expected to be a master.<n>

(E) What’s your favorite color, and what does it mean for you? (F) Who is the most talented singer among your roommates?<n><n>### Answer:(2-6 pts)<n>

If Brenda spends 4 times as much as Janet and has $64 left, how much did Brenda spend?<n><n>Answer:1) Janet: 200 x 2 = $400 <n> Janet spent 4 times as much (Brenda) as Janet.<n><n>Janet's remaining money is: 200 - 60 = $140<n><n>2) Janet: 400 x 2/3 = $266.67<n><n>Janet spent 2 times as much (Brendo) as Janet. Janet's remaining money = 200 - Janet's Spending Amount = 200-266.66 = $63.33<n><n>3) Brendo: Brenda's Spending Amout =200 x 4 = $800<n><n>Her money left = 800 - 64 = $736<n><n>Brenda spent 4 times as Janet and spent 800 dollars ($800).<n><n>Input: In the second game, Janet scored 25 points.
